header_summary: - Johan Torås Halseth provides an update to Antoine on the creation of a demo script for the unilateral exit of participants in a Coinpool using OP_CCV.- Jonas Nick discusses the absence of adaptor signatures in BIP 327 ("MuSig2") and mentions the lack of a security proof for adaptor signatures.- Andrew Chow proposes a new BIP draft for MuSig2 descriptors, focusing on introducing descriptors for working with MuSig2 in Bitcoin Core.- Carla Kirk-Cohen introduces SimLN, a tool that simulates random payment activity on any test lightning network setup, making it easier to test applications and proposals.

recent_posts.title: Solving CoinPool high-interactivity issue with cut-through update of Taproot leaves
recent_posts.summary:
- Johan provides an update to Antoine on the creation of a demo script for unilateral exit in Coinpool using OP_CCV.
- The script demonstrates pubkey and balance commitment, data traversal and modification, and signature validation.
- The script size is 142 bytes and can be further optimized by 20-30%.

recent_posts.title: Proposed BIP for MuSig2 PSBT Fields
recent_posts.summary:
- The email discusses the exclusion of adaptor signatures in BIP 327 ("MuSig2").
- Adaptor signatures were not included due to the complexity of the BIP.
- Adaptor signatures were added to the libsecp256k1-zkp module for experimentation purposes.

recent_posts.title: Proposed BIP for MuSig2 Descriptors
recent_posts.summary:
- Andrew Chow has proposed a new BIP draft for MuSig2 descriptors on GitHub.
- The draft explains the syntax and usage of MuSig2 descriptors in Bitcoin Core.
- The goal is to standardize and simplify the implementation of MuSig2 descriptors in Bitcoin software.

recent_posts.title: SimLN: Simulate active test networks
recent_posts.summary:
- SimLN is a tool that simulates random payment activity on any test lightning network setup.
- It allows you to configure specific payment flows and provides a tool for testing against "busy" networks.
- SimLN automates payment generation, saves time, and offers benefits for testing lightning network applications.

recent_posts.title: Payment Splitting & Switching and its impact on Balance Discovery Attacks (preprint)
recent_posts.summary:
- Gijs van Dam and Tony Giorgio discuss a concept related to decorrelated payments.
- Gijs suggests that the concept could assist with decorrelated payments on an amount analysis level.
- Gijs asks if Tony sees this possibility based on their research write-up from last year.

recent_posts.title: Announcing the Lightning Network Interoperability Initiative
recent_posts.summary:
- Vincent acknowledges the error in his previous post and apologizes for any confusion caused.
- The correct link is not specified in the email, but Vincent provided it in a previous post.
- The email is a brief clarification regarding the incorrect link, signed off with "Cheers".

active_posts.title: Refreshed BIP324
active_posts.summary:
- The BIP324 proposal for a new bitcoin P2P protocol with encryption and upgradability has been refreshed.
- Community members are invited to review the BIP and Bitcoin Core code.
- The proposal includes changes such as Elligator-swift encoding, transport versioning, and shapable handshake.

active_posts.title: Scaling Lightning With Simple Covenants
active_posts.summary:
- Signature-based factories have limitations, but simple covenants enable Lightning channels for casual users.
- Simple covenants can eliminate the bottleneck of obtaining signatures from casual users.
- Timeout-trees and off-chain transactions improve scalability in the Lightning Network.

active_posts.title: Concrete MATT opcodes
active_posts.summary:
- Salvatore Ingala has presented a proposal for the core opcodes of MATT, making it functionally complete.
- The code is implemented in the bitcoin-inquisition repo fork and includes OP_CHECKTEMPLATEVERIFY.
- The changes include introducing OP_CHECKCONTRACTVERIFY opcode and modifying parameter order for better script writing.

active_posts.title: Scaling Lightning With Simple Covenants
active_posts.summary:
- Lightning's scalability challenge can be overcome by enabling simple covenants and timeout-trees.
- Creating Lightning channels for casual users is not scalable under current Bitcoin consensus rules.
- Implementing covenants and timeout-trees would greatly improve Lightning's scalability and usability.

active_posts.title: Practical PTLCs, a little more concretely
active_posts.summary:
- Greg Sanders emphasizes the significance of turning attention to PTLCs as taproot channels are approaching deployment. He provides a GitHub link with a deeper analysis of PTLCs.
- Greg delves into the details of PTLC messages, considering factors like single-sig adaptors, message re-ordering, and updates to mempool/consensus.
- Greg believes his insights on PTLCs can serve as a useful refresher and hopes for discussions and potential standardization efforts, while also welcoming feedback.

active_posts.title: Sidepools For Improving Payment Reliability At Scale
active_posts.summary:
- The sender discusses the challenge of predicting liquidity allocation on the Lightning Network.
- They propose sidepools as a solution for managing funds without closing channels.
- Sidepools can help maintain liquidity, preserve privacy, and mitigate scalability issues on the Lightning Network.
